title: Nifty, Sensex lose ground, bond yields rise as RBI cuts rates
text:
BENGALURU (Reuters) - Indian stock indexes fell and bond yields rose on Friday, after the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) cut interest rates for the fifth time this year as expected, in a bid to boost growth in Asia’s third-largest economy.

The Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) logo is seen under a bull statue at the entrance of their building in Mumbai, India January 30, 2018. REUTERS/Shailesh Andrade/Files

The broader NSE Nifty .NSEI was down 0.03% at 11,310.55 by 1237 local time (0707 GMT), while the benchmark BSE Sensex .BSESN was higher by 0.05% at 38,126.47.

Both indexes had risen roughly 0.4% each earlier on Friday before the rate cuts were announced.

The benchmark 10-year bond yield IN072629G=CC rose 5 basis points to 6.64% after the central bank’s announcement.

The rupee INR=D4 rose 0.13% against the dollar at 70.8425, remaining largely unchanged after the news.

The RBI maintained its “accommodative” stance while announcing the rate cuts and said it would keep that position “as long as it is necessary” to revive economic growth, while ensuring inflation remains within target.

The six-member monetary policy committee (MPC) cut the repo rate INREPO=ECI by 25 basis points to 5.15%, in line with expectations. The reverse repo rate INRREP=ECI was reduced to 4.9%.

India’s economy grew by just 5% in the June quarter, its slowest pace in more than five years, prompting the government to take measures aimed at boosting growth.

A sharp cut in the corporate tax rate - to 22% from 30% - last month brought cheer to markets, but economists say the move will do little to address a lack of spending power.

Leading stock indexes lower after the interest rate cut on Friday were banks, which have already suffered bruising declines in recent sessions.

The Nifty banks index was last down 0.88%, with Federal Bank Ltd’s (FED.NS) 3% drop leading losses on the index.

India’s state-run banks were faring better, with the Nifty PSU banks index that tracks them rising 0.06%.
